variantrule.name: Advantage
entries: If you have Advantage on a {@variantrule D20 Test|Ishiir}, roll two d20s, and use the higher roll. A roll can't be affected by more than one Advantage, and Advantage and {@variantrule Disadvantage|Ishiir} on the same roll cancel each other.

variantrule.name: Disadvantage
entries: If you have Disadvantage on a {@variantrule D20 Test|Ishiir}, roll two d20s and use the lower roll. A roll can't be affected by more than one Disadvantage, and {@variantrule Advantage|Ishiir} and Disadvantage on the same roll cancel each other.

variantrule.name: D20 Test
entries: D20 Tests encompass the three main d20 rolls of the game: {@variantrule Ability Check|Ishiir|Ability Checks}, {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir|Attack Rolls}, and {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir|Saving Throws}. If something in the game affects D20 Tests, it affects all three of these rolls. The DM determines whether a D20 Test is warranted in a given circumstance.

variantrule.name: Ability Check
entries: An Ability Check is a {@variantrule D20 Test|Ishiir} that represents using one of the six abilities—or a specific skill associated with an ability—to overcome a challenge.

variantrule.name: Attack Roll
entries: An Attack Roll is a {@variantrule D20 Test|Ishiir} that represents making an attack with a weapon, an {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|Ishiir}, or a spell.

variantrule.name: Action
entries: On your turn, you can take one action. Choose which action to take from the base set of actions or from the special actions provided by your features.

variantrule.name: Bonus Action
entries: A Bonus Action is a special action that you can take on the same turn that you take an action. You can't take more than one Bonus Action on a turn, and you have a Bonus Action to take only if a rule explicitly says so.

variantrule.name: Reaction
entries: A Reaction is a special action taken in response to a trigger defined in the Reaction's description. You can take a Reaction on another creature's turn, and if you take it on your turn, you can do so even if you also take an action, a {@variantrule Bonus Action|Ishiir}, or both. Once you take a Reaction, you can't take another one until the start of your next turn. The {@action Opportunity Attack|Ishiir} is a Reaction available to all creatures.

variantrule.name: Saving Throw
entries: A Saving Throw—also called a save—represents an attempt to avoid or resist a threat. You normally make a Saving Throw only when a rule requires you to do so, but you can decide to fail the save without rolling. The result of a save is detailed in the effect that allowed it. If a target is forced to make a save and lacks the ability score used by it, the target automatically fails.

variantrule.name: Unarmed Strike
entries: Instead of using a weapon to make a melee attack, you can use a punch, kick, head-butt, or similar forceful blow. In game terms, this is an {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|Ishiir}—a melee attack that involves you using your body to damage, grapple, or shove a target within 5 feet of you.
Whenever you use your {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|Ishiir}, choose one of the following options for its effect.

entries.name: Damage
entries: You make an {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir} against the target. Your bonus to the roll equals your Strength modifier plus your {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir|Proficiency Bonus}. On a hit, the target takes Bludgeoning damage equal to 1 plus your Strength modifier.

entries.name: Grapple
entries: The target must succeed on a Strength or Dexterity {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} (it chooses which), or it has the {@condition Grappled|Ishiir} condition. The DC for the {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} and any escape attempts equals 8 plus your Strength modifier and {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir|Proficiency Bonus}. This grapple is possible only if the target is no more than one size larger than you and if you have a hand free to grab it.

entries.name: Shove
entries: The target must succeed on a Strength or Dexterity {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} (it chooses which), or you either push it 5 feet away or cause it to have the {@condition Prone|Ishiir} condition. The DC for the {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} equals 8 plus your Strength modifier and {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir|Proficiency Bonus}. This shove is possible only if the target is no more than one size larger than you.

variantrule.name: Short Rest
entries: A Short Rest is a period of extended downtime—at least 8 hours—available to any creature. During a Short Rest, you sleep for at least 6 hours and perform no more than 2 hours of light activity, such as reading, talking, eating, or standing watch. During sleep, you have the {@condition Unconscious|Ishiir} condition.

entries.name: Benefits of the Rest
entries: To start a Short Rest, you must have at least 1 Hit Point. When you finish the rest, you gain the following benefits:

items.name: Spend Hit Point Dice
entries: You can spend one or more of your Hit Point Dice to regain Hit Points. For each Hit Point Die you spend in this way, roll the die and add your Constitution modifier to it. You regain Hit Points equal to the total (minimum of 1 Hit Point). You can decide to spend an additional Hit Point Die after each roll.

items.name: Special Feature
entries: Some features are recharged by a Short Rest. If you have such a feature, it recharges in the way specified in its description.

variantrule.name: Long Rest
entries: A Long Rest is a period of extended downtime—at least 7 days—available to any creature in a relatively safe environment.

entries.name: Benefits of the Rest
entries: To start a Long Rest, you must have at least 1 Hit Point. When you finish the rest, you gain the following benefits:

items.name: Regain All HP
entries: You regain all lost Hit Points and half of your spent Hit Point Dice. If your Hit Point maximum was reduced, it returns to normal.

items.name: Ability Scores Restored
entries: If any of your ability scores were reduced, they return to normal.

items.name: Exhaustion Reduced
entries: If you have the {@condition Exhaustion|Ishiir} condition, its level decreases by 1.

items.name: Special Feature
entries: Some features are recharged by a Long Rest. If you have such a feature, it recharges in the way specified in its description.

variantrule.name: Proficiency
entries: If you have proficiency with something, you can add your Proficiency Bonus to any {@variantrule D20 Test|Ishiir} you make using that thing. A creature might have proficiency in a skill or {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} or with a weapon or tool.

variantrule.name: Resistance
entries: If you have Resistance to a {@variantrule Damage Types|Ishiir|damage type}, damage of that type is halved against you (round down). Resistance is applied only once to an instance of damage.

variantrule.name: Immunity
entries: If you have Immunity to a {@variantrule Damage Types|Ishiir|damage type} or a {@variantrule Condition|Ishiir|condition}, it doesn't affect you in any way.

variantrule.name: Damage Types
entries: Attacks and other harmful effects deal different types of damage. Damage types have no rules of their own, but other rules, such as {@variantrule Resistance|Ishiir}, rely on the types. The Damage Types table offers examples to help a DM assign a type to a new effect.

variantrule.name: Condition
entries: A condition is a temporary game state. The definition of a condition says how it affects its recipient, and various rules define how to end a condition. This glossary defines these conditions:
A condition doesn't stack with itself; a recipient either has a condition or doesn't. The {@condition Exhaustion|Ishiir} condition is an exception to that rule.

variantrule.name: Speed
entries: A creature has a Speed, which is the distance in feet the creature can cover when it moves on its turn.

entries.name: Special Speeds
entries: Some creatures have special speeds, such as a {@variantrule Burrow Speed|Ishiir}, {@variantrule Climb Speed|Ishiir}, {@variantrule Fly Speed|Ishiir}, or {@variantrule Swim Speed|Ishiir}, each of which is defined in this glossary. If you have more than one speed, choose which one to use when you move; you can switch between the speeds during your move. Whenever you switch, subtract the distance already moved from the new speed. The result determines how much farther you can move. If the result is 0 or less, you can't use the new speed during the current move. For example, if you have a Speed of 30 and a {@variantrule Fly Speed|Ishiir} of 40, you could fly 10 feet, walk 10 feet, and leap into the air to fly 20 feet more.

entries.name: Changes to Your Speeds
entries: If an effect increases or decreases your Speed for a time, any special speed you have increases or decreases by an equal amount for the same duration. For example, if your Speed is reduced to 0 and you have a {@variantrule Climb Speed|Ishiir}, your {@variantrule Climb Speed|Ishiir} is also reduced to 0. Similarly, if your Speed is halved and you have a {@variantrule Fly Speed|Ishiir}, your {@variantrule Fly Speed|Ishiir} is also halved.

variantrule.name: Burrow Speed
entries: A creature that has a Burrow Speed can use that speed to move through sand, earth, mud, or ice. The creature can't burrow through solid rock unless the creature has a trait that allows it to do so.

variantrule.name: Fly Speed
entries: A Fly Speed can be used to travel through the air. While you have a Fly Speed, you can stay aloft until you land, fall, or die.

variantrule.name: Swim Speed
entries: A Swim Speed can be used to swim without expending the extra movement normally associated with swimming.

variantrule.name: Climb Speed
entries: A Climb Speed can be used in place of {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} to traverse a vertical surface without expending the extra movement normally associated with climbing.

variantrule.name: City Downtime and Activities
entries: While the cities of Ishiir are certainly not free of danger, they provide many opportunities that are not found in the wilderness.

Similar to wilderness travel, the party may engage in different tasks over the course of their time in a city or a comparable safe haven. Unlike during wilderness travel, however, the party need not divide tasks up amongst them and can pursue the same tasks as other party members or even none at all without immediate negative repercussions.
As before, the adventuring day is divided into three 8-hour-segments or phases: business time, downtime, and rest.

entries.name: Tasks
entries: A character can perform tasks during business time, downtime, or both. If the character performs tasks during both, any progress towards their {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir} is reset.

entries.name: Attend
entries: A character performs this task by offering their services as a healer, physician, or surgeon. To attend the designated character makes a skill check against the area DC.
The result is determined by the difference between the roll and the DC and can be referenced on the Attending table.

entries.name: Carouse
entries: A character performs this task by touring the taverns of the area, getting absolutely smashed, and quite possibly into a lot of trouble. To carouse the designated character makes a Constitution {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} against the area DC.
The result is determined by the difference between the roll and the DC. Regardless of the result, the character then rolls on the Carousing event table.

entries.name: Craft
entries: A character performs this task by using his proficiency with a tool to create or refine goods. To craft the designated character makes a skill check against the area DC.
The result is determined by the difference between the roll and the DC and can be referenced on the Crafting table.

entries.name: Gamble
entries: A character performs this task by engaging in games of chance, though often with strategic elements, and/or the opportunity to cheat. To gamble the designated character makes a skill check against the area DC. The character can choose to cheat. If they do so, they make the skill check with advantage and all die rolls associated with the result, both positive and negative, are maximized. Further, certain negative events can only occur during cheating.
The result is determined by the difference between the roll and the DC and can be referenced on the Gambling table

entries.name: Guard
entries: A character performs this task by offering their services as a city guard, bodyguard, or even hired thug. To guard the designated character makes a skill check against the area DC.
The result is determined by the difference between the roll and the DC and can be referenced on the Guarding table.

entries.name: Haggle
entries: A character performs this task by engaging with different merchants and trying to negotiate the best deals for selling and buying goods. To haggle the designated character makes a skill check against the area DC.
The result is determined by the difference between the roll and the DC and can be referenced on the Haggling table.

entries.name: Perform
entries: A character performs this task by performing as an actor or musician for the entertainment of a crowd. To perform the designated character makes a skill check against the area DC.
The result is determined by the difference between the roll and the DC and can be referenced on the Performing table.

entries.name: Pickpocket
entries: A character performs this task by attempting to lift coin and valuables from unsuspecting victims while remaining unnoticed. To pickpocket the designated character makes a skill check against the area DC.
The result is determined by the difference between the roll and the DC and can be referenced on the Pickpocketing table.

entries.caption: Attend
rows: Difference x {@dice 1d8} x character level cp, positive attending event, roll twice and take higher
Difference x {@dice 1d6} x character level cp, positive attending event
Difference x {@dice 1d4} x character level cp
Negative attending event, roll twice and take lower

entries.caption: Carouse
rows: Roll thrice on the carousing table and take higher
Roll twice on the carousing table and take higher
Roll once on the carousing table
Roll once on the carousing table
Roll twice on the carousing table and take lower
Roll thrice on the carousing table and take lower

Difference x {@dice 1d6} x character level cp, positive crafting event
Difference x {@dice 1d4} x character level cp
Negative crafting event, roll twice and take lower

Negative pickpocketing event, roll twice and take lower

entries.name: Fame
entries: When performing tasks, characters may earn fame in certain locations or with certain factions. All characters start at out 0 fame and may have a maximum fame equal to their proficiency. A character's fame can be negative.

If a character's task is performed in a location or for a faction with which they have fame, their fame is added to each individual die they roll to determine the result of their task, e.g. with 2 fame that normally rolls {@dice 2d4}, rolls {@dice 2d4+4} instead.

entries.name: Area Difficulty
entries: Below is the table for DC modifiers on generic location types. Note that story events and other factors can also influence the final roll result. But the table below can be used by characters to generally evaluate their chances and determine activities.

variantrule.name: Heroic Inspiration
entries: If you (a player character) have Heroic Inspiration, you can expend it to reroll any die immediately after rolling it, and you must use the new roll.

variantrule.name: Mark of Fate
entries: If you (a player character) has a Mark of Fate, you can expend it to add a +5 bonus to any {@variantrule D20 Test|Ishiir} immediately after rolling it.

variantrule.name: Spellcasting
entries: This section expands on the spellcasting rules presented in the {@book Player's Handbook|PHB|10} and the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG}, providing clarifications and new options.

entries.name: Perceiving a Caster at Work
entries: Many spells create obvious effects: explosions of fire, walls of ice, teleportation, and the like. Other spells, such as charm person, display no visible, audible, or otherwise perceptible sign of their effects, and could easily go unnoticed by someone unaffected by them. As noted in the {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}, you normally don't know that a spell has been cast unless the spell produces a noticeable effect.

But what about the act of casting a spell? Is it possible for someone to perceive that a spell is being cast in their presence? To be perceptible, the casting of a spell must involve a verbal, somatic, or material component. The form of a material component doesn't matter for the purposes of perception, whether it's an object specified in the spell's description, a component pouch, or a spellcasting focus.

If the need for a spell's components has been removed by a special ability, such as the sorcerer's Subtle Spell feature or the Innate Spellcasting trait possessed by many creatures, the casting of the spell is imperceptible. If an imperceptible casting produces a perceptible effect, it's normally impossible to determine who cast the spell in the absence of other evidence.

entries.name: Identifying a Spell
entries: Sometimes a character wants to identify a spell that someone else is casting or that was already cast. To do so, a character can use their reaction to identify a spell as it's being cast, or they can use an action on their turn to identify a spell by its effect after it is cast.

If the character perceived the casting, the spell's effect, or both, the character can make an Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check with their reaction or action. The DC equals 15 + the spell's level. If the spell is cast as a class spell and the character is a member of that class, the check is made with advantage. For example, if the spellcaster casts a spell as a cleric, another cleric has advantage on the check to identify the spell. Some spells aren't associated with any class when they're cast, such as when a monster uses its Innate Spellcasting trait.

This Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check represents the fact that identifying a spell requires a quick mind and familiarity with the theory and practice of casting. This is true even for a character whose spellcasting ability is Wisdom or Charisma. Being able to cast spells doesn't by itself make you adept at deducing exactly what others are doing when they cast their spells.

entries.name: Invalid Spell Targets
entries: A spell specifies what a caster can target with it: any type of creature, a creature of a certain type (humanoid or beast, for instance), an object, an area, the caster, or something else. But what happens if a spell targets something that isn't a valid target? For example, someone might cast {@spell Charm Person|Ishiir} on a creature believed to be a humanoid, not knowing that the target is in fact a vampire. If this issue comes up, handle it using the following rule.

If you {@action Magic|Ishiir|cast a spell} on someone or something that can't be affected by the spell, nothing happens to that target, but if you used a spell slot to cast the spell, the slot is still expended. If the spell normally has no effect on a target that succeeds on a saving throw, the invalid target appears to have succeeded on its saving throw, even though it didn't attempt one (giving no hint that the creature is in fact an invalid target). Otherwise, you perceive that the spell did nothing to the target.

entries.name: Areas of Effect on a Grid
entries: The Dungeon Master's Guide includes the following short rule for using areas of effect on a grid.

Choose an intersection of squares as the point of origin of an area of effect, then follow the rules for that kind of area as normal (see the "{@book Areas of Effect|PHB|10|Areas of Effect}" section in chapter 10 of the {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}). If an area of effect is circular and covers at least half a square, it affects that square.

That rule works, but it can require a fair amount of on-the-spot adjudication. This section offers two alternatives for determining the exact location of an area: the template method and the token method. Both of these methods assume you're using a grid and miniatures of some sort. Because these methods can yield different results for the number of squares in a given area, it's not recommended that they be combined at the table—choose whichever method you and your players find easier or more intuitive.

entries.name: Template Method
entries: The template method uses two-dimensional shapes that represent different areas of effect. The aim of the method is to accurately portray the length and width of each area on the grid and to leave little doubt about which creatures are affected by it. You'll need to make these templates or find premade ones.

entries.name: Making a Template
entries: Making a template is simple. Get a piece of paper or card stock, and cut it in the shape of the area of effect you're using. Every 5 feet of the area equals 1 inch of the template's size. For example, the 20-foot-radius sphere of the {@spell Fireball|Ishiir} spell, which has a 40-foot diameter, would translate into a circular template with an 8-inch diameter.

entries.name: Using a Template
entries: To use an area-of-effect template, apply it to the grid. If the terrain is flat, you can lay it on the surface; otherwise, hold the template above the surface and take note of which squares it covers or partially covers. If any part of a square is under the template, that square is included in the area of effect. If a creature's miniature is in an affected square, that creature is in the area. Being adjacent to the edge of the template isn't enough for a square to be included in the area of effect; the square must be entirely or partly covered by the template.
You can also use this method without a grid. If you do so, a creature is included in an area of effect if any part of the miniature's base is overlapped by the template.

When you place a template, follow all the rules in the {@book Player's Handbook|PHB} for placing the associated area of effect. If an area of effect, such as a cone or a line, originates from a spellcaster, the template should extend out from the caster and be positioned however the caster likes within the bounds of the rules.
Diagrams 2.1 and 2.2 show the template method in action.

entries.name: Token Method
entries: The token method is meant to make areas of effect tactile and fun. To use this method, grab some dice or other tokens, which you're going to use to represent your areas of effect.

Rather than faithfully representing the shapes of the different areas of effect, this method gives you a way to create square-edged versions of them on a grid easily, as described in the following subsections.

entries.name: Using Tokens
entries: Every 5-foot square of an area of effect becomes a die or other token that you place on the grid. Each token goes inside a square, not at an intersection of lines. If an area's token is in a square, that square is included in the area of effect. It's that simple.
Diagrams 2.3 through 2.6 show this method in action, using dice as the tokens.

entries.name: Circles
entries: This method depicts everything using squares, and a circular area of effect becomes square in it, whether the area is a sphere, cylinder, or radius. For instance, the 10-foot radius of flame strike, which has a diameter of 20 feet, is expressed as a square that is 20 feet on a side, as shown in diagram 2.3. Diagram 2.4 shows that area with {@quickref Cover||3||total cover} inside it.

entries.name: Cones
entries: A cone is represented by rows of tokens on the grid, extending from the cone's point of origin. In the rows, the squares are adjoining side by side or corner to corner, as shown in diagram 2.5. To determine the number of rows a cone contains, divide its length by 5. For example, a 30-foot cone contains six rows.

Here's how to create the rows. Starting with a square adjacent to the cone's point of origin, place one token. The square can be orthogonally or diagonally adjacent to the point of origin. In every row beyond that one, place as many tokens as you placed in the previous row, plus one more token. Place this row's tokens so that their squares each share a side with a square in the previous row. If the cone is orthogonally adjacent to the point of origin, you'll have one more token to place in the row; place it on one end or the other of the row you just created (you don't have to pick the side chosen in diagram 2.5). Keep placing tokens in this way until you've created all of the cone's rows.

entries.name: Lines
entries: A line can extend from its source orthogonally or diagonally, as shown in diagram 2.6.

variantrule.name: Fortitude Points
entries: Fortitude Points, hereafter shortened to FP, form a pool of quasi-temporary hitpoints that stack with all other forms of hitpoints. FP replace the reworked Legendary Resistance system for monsters.

When a creature with FP fails a {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} and is at 50% HP or less, it takes an amount of damage to its FP that corresponds to the power of the effect. As an example, a spell would consume an amount of FP equal to 10 x its spell level.

If the amount of FP the effect would consume is greater than the amount of FP the creature has remaining, the remaining FP is consumed AND the creature is subject to the effect as normal. There is NOT, however, any carryover of the excess "damage" the ability would've caused to the FP pool.

If a creature would drop to 0 hp, but has FP remaining, the damage is subtracted from the FP first instead. This happens at a 1:1 ratio, so an attack doing 8 points of damage would consume 8 points of FP.

entries.caption: Effect Damage to FP
rows: Spirits: Spirit Tales (Tale of the Beguiler)
Spirits: Spirit Tales (Tale of the Brute)
Spirits: Spirit Tales (Tale of the Dragon)
Spirits: Spirit Tales (Tale of the Mind-Bender)
30 (40 at Lvl 10, 50 at Lvl 13, 60 at Lvl 17)
Ascendant Dragon: Breath of the Dragon
Ascendant Dragon: Aspect of the Wyrm (Frightful Presence)
Astral Self: (Arms of the Astral Self)
Long Death: Touch of the L. Death
Tranquility: Douse the Flames of War
10 x Number of Sneak Attack dice spent
Giant Soul: Soul of Lost Ostoria (Hill Giant)
Spider Queen: Kiss of the Spider Queen
Lurker in the Deep: Devouring Maw
Lurker in the Deep: Unleash the Depths

variantrule.name: Overland Travel and Survival
entries: Traveling Ishiir, especially its wilderness, is a dangerous undertaking. Dividing labor among the characters wisely goes a long way towards making sure the party survives their challenges.
The adventuring day is divided into three 8-hour-segments or phases: travel, downtime, and rest.

entries.name: Travel Pace
entries: While traveling, a group of Adventurers can move at a normal, fast, or slow pace, as shown on the Travel Pace table. The table states how far the party can move in a period of time and whether the pace has any additional effect. A fast pace gives characters less time to be thorough in performing their tasks, while a slow pace makes it possible to sneak around and to search an area more carefully during this phase.

entries.name: Forced March
entries: The Travel Pace table assumes that Characters Travel for 8 hours in a day. They can push on beyond that limit, at the risk of {@condition Exhaustion|Ishiir}.

For each additional hour of Travel beyond 8 hours, the Characters cover the distance shown in the Hour column for their pace, but once the characters stop traveling, they have to make a Constitution {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir}.

The DC is 10 + 1 for each hour past 8 hours. On a failed {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir}, a character suffers one level of {@condition Exhaustion|Ishiir} (see {@filter Conditions|conditionsdiseases|source=Ishiir}).

entries.name: Difficult Terrain
entries: The Travel speeds given in the Travel Pace table assume relatively simple terrain: roads, open plains, or clear dungeon corridors.

But Adventurers often face dense forests, deep swamps, rubble-filled ruins, steep mountains, and ice-covered groundall considered {@quickref Difficult Terrain||3}. Characters moving through {@quickref difficult terrain||3} only cover half the distance in the same amount of time.

entries.name: Tasks
entries: At the beginning of each phase, the party can choose to designate tasks to each of their members. Tasks can range from leading the party through the wilderness, over foraging for food or looking for tracks, to tracking an adversary. Tasks can be assigned for any phase during which the party isn't resting.
Unless they have a feature that says otherwise, a character can only work on one assigned task during each phase.

The party may also choose to assign an additional character to assist another one in the same task. If they do so, the originally assigned character benefits from the Help action. A character may only assist in the task if they are proficient in the skill used by the check or another appropriate one as laid out in the Task table below.
If no character is assigned to a task, a d20 without any modifiers is rolled in place of a skill check. In the case of foraging, the roll and check against the DC is omitted entirely.

entries.name: Pathfind
entries: A character that performs this task is leading the group through whichever area they're traveling. This check includes finding the quickest and safest path for the group to their destination as well as avoiding random encounters.
To pathfind, the designated character makes a skill check against the area DC. The result is determined by the difference between the roll and the DC and can be referenced on the Pathfinding table.

entries.name: Forage
entries: A character that forages, gathers, fishes, or hunts for food while the party is traveling. Alternatively, a character can instead forage for ingredients used in crafting for Herbalism and Alchemy.

To forage, the designated character makes a skill check opposed by an area DC roll from the DM. The result is determined by the difference between the roll and the DC and can be referenced on the Foraging table.

entries.name: Lookout
entries: A character on lookout duty surveys the surrounding area, scouts ahead, or otherwise keeps an eye out. In the case of a hostile encounter, a lookout can prevent the party being {@condition Surprised|Ishiir} or even grant the party surprise in turn. A lookout may also notice things farther in the distance like hints, treasure, or points of interest.

To look out, the designated character makes a skill check opposed by an area DC roll from the DM. The result is determined by the difference between the roll and the DC and can be referenced on the Lookout table.

There can be up to two random combat encounters over the course of the adventuring day, either during the travel or rest phase. If multiple rolls result in a combat encounter for a given phase, its difficulty is treated as higher (1 for medium, 2 for hard, 3 for deadly), up to a maximum of triple deadly.

entries.caption: Pathfind
rows: No encounter, the party travels as if 1 speed category faster (+10 miles if already using fast pace), positive pathfinding event
No encounter, the party travels as if 1 speed category faster (+10 miles if already using fast pace)

entries.caption: Forage (Food)
rows: Negative foraging event, roll twice and take lower

entries.caption: Forage (Ingredients)
rows: Difference x {@dice 1d8} x character level sp worth of ingredients, positive foraging event
Difference x {@dice 1d8} x character level sp worth of ingredients
Difference x {@dice 1d4} x character level sp worth of ingredients
Negative foraging event, roll twice and take lower

entries.caption: Lookout
rows: +{@dice 1d8} to initiative for first combat on this day, positive lookout event
Party receives +5 to stealth check, counts towards Prepare Campsite checks if no encounter happens during Travel phase
+{@dice 1d8} to initiative for first combat on this day
Negative lookout event, roll twice and take lower

entries.name: Downtime
entries: During downtime, characters can craft, forage, and look out as during the Travel phase (albeit with disadvantage), and prepare the campsite for the rest phase.

To prepare the campsite, the designated character makes a skill check opposed by an area DC roll from the DM. The result is determined by the difference between the roll and the DC and can be referenced on the Prepare Campsite table.

entries.caption: Prepare Campsite
rows: Lower difficulty of nighttime encounter from events by 2 steps (lower than medium = no encounter)
Lower difficulty of nighttime encounter from events by 1 step (lower than medium = no encounter)

entries.name: Rest
entries: The characters complete a {@variantrule Short Rest|Ishiir}. The rest is divided into four 2-hour shifts, during which at least one character should keep watch. If any of the previous checks resulted in a nighttime encounter, the result of a {@dice d4} determines during which shift the encounter happens.

entries.name: Area Difficulty
entries: Below is the table for DC modifiers on generic terrain types. Note that story events and other factors can also influence the final roll result. But the table below can be used by characters to generally evaluate their chances and determine travel paths.

variantrule.name: Carrying Capacity
entries: The carrying capacity of a creature is halved if the creature is small, and halved again if the creature is tiny.

variantrule.name: Class and Subclass Features
entries: ALL classes and subclasses that gain a fighting style from a feature can choose from all styles available to the Fighter class, rather than only a limited selection.
Barbarians may add their rage damage bonus to ranged weapon attacks with thrown weapons.

Class features that require a {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} and do not normally use the spell save DC of the class and do not have a dedicated item to increase their DC, instead receive the enhancement bonus of an item used through the feature (where appropriate). Features that do not involve any items, such as certain racial abilities or other class features, instead receive a bonus to their DC equal to half proficiency, rounded down.

variantrule.name: Combat
entries: Features that refer to a weapon damage die, reference the entire base damage of the weapon. E.g. for the Barbarian's Brutal Critical feature, you can roll an additional {@dice 2d6} on a critical hit with a greatsword, rather than only {@dice 1d6}.
Death {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir|Saving Throws} do not reset once a creature heals, they instead recharge on a {@variantrule Short Rest|Ishiir|Short} or a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir}.
Dodging also gives disadvantage on attempts to grapple against the dodging creature.

variantrule.name: Feats
entries: In addition to the Ability Score Increases/Feats granted as per each class section, each character gains an additional feat at first and tenth CHARACTER level.

The feat picked at first level is the character's Origin Feat and will gain additional and/or stronger features based on the character's deeds as he continues growing in power at 5th, 11th and 17th CHARACTER level. The DM decides the exact nature of these changes.
A grapple attempt counts as melee attack for the purpose of interacting with the Mobile feat.

variantrule.name: Magic
entries: Being raised from the dead removes ALL {@condition Exhaustion|Ishiir} levels rather than one if the spell creates a new body as part of its effect.
Creatures that are levitating, such as through the {@spell Levitate|Ishiir} spell, can use half their fly speed to move around if they have any.

variantrule.name: Armor Mastery
entries: If you possess the Martial Mastery class feature, you can apply a mastery to any {@filter armor|items|source=ishiir|type=|category=|homebrew mastery=!none;light;medium;heavy} you have proficiency in once per rest. You can change your choice when you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|Ishiir|Short} or a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir}.

variantrule.name: Weapon Mastery
entries: When you make a weapon attack, you can choose a mastery available to your {@filter weapon|items|source=ishiir|type=|category=|homebrew mastery=!none;!light;!medium;!heavy} if you possess the Martial Mastery class feature. Only one mastery may be applied to any given attack.
Mastery save DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Strength or Dexterity modifier (your choice)

variantrule.name: Bloodied
entries: A creature is Bloodied while it has half its Hit Points or fewer remaining.

variantrule.name: Spell Slot Conversion
entries: Characters that have the Spellcasting class feature can use an action to convert unexpended spell slots of any level into spell slots of a different level.

You may choose to convert multiple spell slots into a single larger spell slot, vice versa, or a mix thereof, e.g. you can choose to convert two 3rd level spell slots into a single 6th level slot, a 4th and three 1st level spell slots, or two 2nd level and four 1st level spell slots.
The table below shows the point value of each spell level. The point value sum of the spell slots you convert must be equal to the point value sum of the resulting spell levels.
Note that you cannot have more spell slots for a given spell level than shown on your class progression table at any point.
